[[SES S.A.]] (2011-2014) | website = | COSPAR_ID = 1998-063B | SATCAT = | mission_duration = {{age in years and months|1998|10|28|2014|05|17}} | spacecraft_bus = [[Spacebus 2000]] | manufacturer = [[Dornier Flugzeugwerke|Dornier]]
[[Aérospatiale]] | dry_mass = | launch_mass = {{convert|1698|kg}} | power = | launch_date = {{start-date|28 October 1998, 22:15:00|timezone=yes}} UTC | launch_rocket = [[Ariane 4|Ariane 44L]] | launch_site = [[Guiana Space Centre|Kourou]] [[ELA-2]] | launch_contractor = [[Arianespace]] | entered_service = | disposal_type = [[Graveyard orbit]] | deactivated = {{end-date|17 May 2014}} | orbit_epoch = | orbit_reference = [[Geocentric orbit|Geocentric]] | orbit_regime = [[Geostationary orbit|Geostationary]] | orbit_periapsis = {{convert|35777|km|mi}} | orbit_apoapsis = {{convert|35796|km|mi}} | orbit_inclination = 0.03 degrees | orbit_period = | orbit_longitude = [[79th meridian west|79° West]] | apsis = gee | trans_band = 16 [[J band (NATO)|J band]] (IEEE [[Ku band]]) | trans_frequency = | trans_capacity = | trans_coverage = | trans_TWTA = | trans_EIRP = | trans_HPBW = }} The '''AMC-5''', originally called '''GE-5''', was a [[geosynchronous]] [[direct-broadcast satellite]] located at 79 degrees west longitude, operated by [[SES Americom]] in the [[Ku band|Ku band]]. It was used by a variety of television customers, including being home to the [[CBS Newspath]] service.{{cite web|title=AMC-5|publisher=CBS Newspath|format=PDF|url=http://www.cbsnewspath.com/satellite/AMC5Newspath.pdf|access-date=2009-02-25|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110708124832/http://www.cbsnewspath.com/satellite/AMC5Newspath.pdf|archive-date=2011-07-08|dead-url=yes|df=}} The satellite was retired and moved to a [[graveyard orbit]] on 17 May 2014 after 15 years of service.{{cite web |url=http://licensing.fcc.gov/myibfs/download.do?attachment_key=1048011 |title=Retirement of AMC-5 (Call Sign S2156), File No. SAT-MOD-20130325-00054 |author=SatCom Law LLC |publisher=[[Federal Communications Commission]] |format=PDF |date=2014-05-23 |accessdate=9 April 2016}} ==Payload & Specifications== [[File:Amc5H.jpg|thumb|AMC-5 Horizontal Transponders On Scope]] '''Spacecraft design:''' [[Alcatel-Lucent|Alcatel]] Spacebus 2000
'''Orbital location:''' 79°W
'''Launch Date:''' October 28, 1998
'''Vehicle:''' Ariane 44L
'''Design life:''' 15 years
'''Band:''' [[Ku band|Ku band]] '''Ku-band payload:''' 16 x 54 MHz
'''Transponder type:''' [[TWTA]], 55-watt
'''Transponder redundancy:''' 11 for 8
'''Receiver redundancy:''' 4 for 2
'''Coverage:''' [[CONUS]], Southern Canada, Northern Mexico{{cite web|title=AMC-5|publisher=SES|url=http://www.ses.com/4628299/amc-5|access-date=2013-10-29|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120110054534/http://www.ses.com/4628299/amc-5|archive-date=2012-01-10|dead-url=yes|df=}} == References == {{reflist}} {{Portal|Spaceflight}} {{Fairchild Aircraft}} {{SES World Skies}} {{Orbital launches in 1998}} {{Use American English|date=January 2014}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Amc-05}} [[Category:Communications satellites in geostationary orbit]] [[Category:Spacecraft launched in 1998]] [[Category:SES satellites]] [[Category:Satellites using the Spacebus bus]] {{communications-satellite-stub}} {{Netherlands-spacecraft-stub|nocat=yes}}

revision.text:
{{Infobox sport governing body |name = Automobile Club de Monaco |abbrev = |logo = |logosize = |sport = Motorsport |category = |image = Facade of Automobile Club de Monaco.jpg |caption = Headquarters of Automobile Club de Monaco |jurisdiction = Monaco |founded = {{Start date|1890}} as SVM
{{Start date|1925}} as the ACM |aff = |affdate = |region = |regionyear = |headquarters = Monte Carlo |location = |president = [[Michel Boeri]] |vicepresident = |director = |secretary = |year closed = |url = https://acm.mc/en/accueil/ }} The '''Automobile Club de Monaco''' is a [[motoring club]] based in [[Monaco]]. The club serves as the [[Sports governing body|governing body]] for motorsport within Monaco, and organises the prestigious [[Monaco Grand Prix]] and [[Monte Carlo Rally]]. It is a member of the [[Fédération Internationale de l'Automobile]], representing Monaco as a mobility and sporting club. Founded in 1890 as an association of cyclists, the ''Sport Vélocipédique Monégasque'', the club began to incorporate motorists in 1907 and was renamed the ''Sport Vélocipédique et Automobile Monégasque''. Alexandre Noghès, the SVAM's president, started planning the principality's first international motorsport event, the [[Monte Carlo Rally]], at the behest of [[Albert I, Prince of Monaco]]. The rally would start at points across Europe, and converge on Monaco to finish.{{cite web|title=Monaco profile|url=http://www.grandprix.com/gpe/cir-047.html|website=GrandPrix.com|accessdate=7 September 2015}} The club ceased to organise cycling events following the First World War and was renamed the ''Automobile Club de Monaco'' in 1925. The ACM applied to the AIACR (the forerunner to the FIA) to be upgraded from a regional French club to a full national member, but had their application refused because no motorsport event was held entirely within Monaco's borders.Hughes, M. 2007. ''Street theatre 1929''. '''Motor Sport''', LXXXIII/3, p. 62 [[Antony Noghès]], the son of the club's President, organised the inaugural Monaco Grand Prix in [[1929 Monaco Grand Prix|1929]] on a circuit [[Circuit de Monaco|around the streets of Monaco]], and the ACM was promptly admitted to the AIACR. The Monaco Grand Prix was part of the [[European Championship (auto racing)|European Championship]] in the 1930s, and was included in the inaugural [[Formula One World Championship]] in 1950. The Grand Prix has been held continuously since 1955, and despite minor modifications over the years, it is still largely run over the same circuit as the inaugural race in 1929. The ACM also organises the [[Historic Grand Prix of Monaco]], a series of races for [[Historic motorsport|historic]] Grand Prix cars held over the Circuit de Monaco, and the Rallye Monte-Carlo Historique [[classic rally]]. Other motorsport events held by the club include the [[Monaco ePrix]] and the [[Junior Monaco Kart Cup]]. == References == {{Reflist}} {{Sports governing bodies in Monaco}} [[Category:Motorsport in Monaco]] [[Category:Sports governing bodies in Monaco]] [[Category:National sporting authorities of the FIA]] [[Category:Monaco stubs]] {{Monaco-stub}}

[[File:Balkan federation.png|250px|thumb|[[Comintern]] project on Balkan Federation.]]
The '''Balkan Federation''' project was a [[left-wing]] political movement to create a "Balkan federation".<ref>''Balkan federation: a history of the movement toward Balkan unity in modern times'', Smith College studies in history, Leften Stavros Stavrianos, Archon Books, 1964, p. 149.</ref>
The concept of a Balkan federation emerged in the late 19th century from among left political forces in the region. The central aim was to establish a new political unity: a common federal republic unifying the [[Balkan Peninsula]] on the basis of [[Internationalism (politics)|internationalism]], [[socialism]], [[social solidarity]], and [[economic equality]]. The underlying vision was that despite differences among the Balkan peoples the historical need for emancipation was a common basis for unification.
This political concept went through three phases in its development. In the first phase the idea was articulated as a response to the collapse of the [[Ottoman Empire]] at the beginning of the 20th century. In the second phase, mostly through the interwar period (1919–36), the idea of the Balkan federation was taken up by the Balkan Communist parties. The third phase is characterized by the clash between the Balkan Communist leaders and [[Joseph Stalin]], who opposed the idea during the post-[[World War II]] period.
== Background == [[File:Flag of Rigas Feraios.svg|thumb|left|[[Rigas Feraios]]'s envisioned pan-Balkan federation flag.]] At first, in Belgrade in 1865 a number of radical Balkan intellectuals founded the Democratic Oriental Federation, proposing a federation from the [[Alps]] to [[Cyprus]] based on political freedom and social equality. They confirmed their adherence to the ideals of French Revolution in the line of [[Claude Henri de Rouvroy, comte de Saint-Simon|Saint-Simon]]'s federalism and in relation to the socialist ideas of [[Karl Marx]] or [[Mikhail Bakunin]]. Later, in France, a League for the Balkan Confederation, was constituted in 1894, in which Greek, Bulgarian, Serbian, and Romanian socialists participated, supporting Macedonian autonomy inside the general federation of Southeast Europe, as an attempt to deal with the complexity of the [[Macedonian Question]]. The next attempt came immediately after the [[Young Turk Revolution]] in 1908. The following year, in Salonika, the Socialist Workers Association merged with two Bulgarian socialist groups, and the [[Socialist Workers' Federation|Socialist Worker's Federation of Ottoman Workers]] was founded. This group underestimated, till 1913, the political significance of [[nationalism]], as this significance manifested itself in the right of national self-determination. Its leadership kept a moderate position in regard with the nationalistic tendencies in Balkan [[social democracy|social democratic]] parties.
=== Balkan Socialist Federation ===
The movement for Balkan Socialist Federation arose after the [[Young Turk Revolution]] in 1908. The First Balkan Socialist Conference was held on January 7-9, 1910 in [[Belgrade]]. The main platforms at this conference were Balkan unity and action against the impending wars. Another important aspect was the call for a solution to the Macedonian Question. In 1915, after a conference in [[Bucharest]], it was decided to create a Revolutionary Balkan Social Democratic Labour Federation, comprising groups which adhered to the [[Zimmerwald Conference]] and opposed participation in [[World War I]]. Initially headed by [[Christian Rakovsky]], it had [[Vasil Kolarov]] and [[Georgi Dimitrov]] among its prominent activists. In 1915, Dimitrov wrote that [[Macedonia (region)|Macedonia]], "... which was split into three parts ...", would be, "... reunited into a single state enjoying equal rights within the framework of the Balkan Democratic Federation." <ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.marxists.org/reference/archive/dimitrov/works/1915/balkan.htm|title=''The Significance of the Second Balkan Conference''|author=Georgi Dimitrov|accessdate=August 2, 2006| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20060904212109/http://www.marxists.org/reference/archive/dimitrov/works/1915/balkan.htm| archivedate= 4 September 2006 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref> This independent and united Macedonia would have consisted of the corresponding geographical departments of Bulgaria, Yugoslavia, and Greece. The leaders of the Federation were repressed by the Balkan governments at different intervals. Rakovsky was expelled from various Balkan countries and, during World War I, became a founding member of the Revolutionary Balkan Social Democratic Labor Federation. Later he made his way to Russia, where he joined the [[Bolshevik Party]] after the October Revolution in 1917, and subsequently Dimitrov, Kolarov, and Rakovsky became members of the [[Comintern]].
=== Balkan Communist Federation ===
After the [[October Revolution|Russian October Revolution]], a Balkan [[Communism|Communist]] Federation was formed in 1920–1921, and was influenced by [[Vladimir Lenin]]'s views on nationality (''see [[Proletarian internationalism]]''). It was a Communist umbrella organisation in which all the Communist parties in the Balkans were represented. It was dominated by the requirements imposed by the [[Soviet Union]] through the Comintern. It advocated a "Balkan Federative Republic" that would have included [[Bulgaria]], [[Kingdom of Yugoslavia|Yugoslavia]], [[Greece]], and [[Turkey]]; some projects also involved [[Romania]], but most of them only envisaged its fragmentation.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Koutalis|first1=Vangelis|title=''Internationalism as an Alternative Political Strategy in the Modern History of Balkans''|url=http://www.okde.org/keimena/vag_kout_balkan_inter_0603_en.htm|website=Organization of Communist Internationalists of Greece–Spartacus|accessdate=25 April 2017|date=June 2003}}</ref> The body thus oversaw the activities of the [[Bulgarian Communist Party]] (BKP), the [[League of Communists of Yugoslavia|Communist Party of Yugoslavia]] (KPJ), the [[Communist Party of Greece]] (KKE), the [[Communist Party of Turkey (historical)|Communist Party of Turkey]] (TKP), and, to a certain measure, those of the [[Romanian Communist Party|Communist Party of Romania]] (PCdR). It was disestablished in 1939.
In [[Sofia]], Bulgaria, May–June 1922, the question of the "autonomy of Macedonia, [[Dobruja]] and [[Thrace]]" was raised by [[Vasil Kolarov]] and was backed by Dimitrov, the Bulgarian delegate who presided over the meeting. The Greek delegate asked for a postponement as he was reluctant to approve a motion that was not on the agenda. In December 1923, the Balkan Communist Federation held its Fifth Conference in [[Moscow]]. In 1924 the Comintern entered negotiations about collaboration between the Communists and the [[Internal Macedonian Revolutionary Organization]] (IMRO), [[Internal Thracian Revolutionary Organisation]] (ITRO) and [[Internal Dobrujan Revolutionary Organisation]] (IDRO), and the creation of a united revolutionary movement. The idea for a new unified organization was supported by the Soviet Union, which saw a chance for using this well developed revolutionary movements to spread revolution in the Balkans and destabilize the Balkan monarchies.
The so-called [[May Manifesto]] of 6 May 1924 was issued in which the objectives of the unified Macedonian liberation movement were presented: independence and unification of partitioned Macedonia, fighting all the neighbouring Balkan monarchies, forming a Balkan Communist Federation and cooperation with the Soviet Union. In 1925, under the influence of the BKP, several left-wing splinter groups (the [[Internal Macedonian Revolutionary Organization (United)]], the Dobrujan Revolutionary Organisation and the Internal Thracian Organization), respectively, seceded from the main organizations. These wings militated for their own Soviet Republics, which would be part of a "Balkan Communist Federation". The BKP was compelled by Stalin to endorse the formation of [[Macedonians (ethnic group)|Macedonian]], Thracian, and [[Dobruja]]n nations in order to include those new separate states in the Balkan Communist Federation.<ref name="Rothschild">{{cite book | last =Rothschild | first =Joseph | title =The Communist Party of Bulgaria: Origins and Development, 1883–1936 | publisher =Columbia University Press | page =126 | isbn = }} </ref> <ref name="Cook">{{cite book | last =A. Cook | first =Bernard | title =Europe Since 1945: An Encyclopedia | publisher =Taylor & Francis | year =2001 | page =810 | isbn =0-8153-4058-3 }}</ref><ref>{{cite book | last =Coenen-Huther | first =Jacques | title =Bulgaria at the Crossroads | publisher =Nova Publishers | year =1996 | page =166 | isbn =1-56072-305-X }}</ref> Later, a [[Resolution of the Comintern on the Macedonian Question|resolution of the Balkan Communist Federation]] for the recognition of a Macedonian ethnicity was issued on January 7, 1934, by the Balkan Secretariat of the Comintern. It was accepted by the Political Secretariat in Moscow on January 11, 1934, and approved by the Executive Committee of the Comintern.
The KKE delegate Nikolaos Sargologos signed the motion without central authorisation; instead of returning to [[Athens]], he emigrated to the [[United States]]. The KKE political organ and newspaper, ''[[Rizospastis]]'', was against the motion because it saw it as good for the BKP in Bulgaria but disastrous for the KKE in Greece. The KKE found the BCF's position on Macedonia difficult but briefly went along with it. In June 1924, at its 5th meeting, it recognised "the Macedonian people" and in December 1924, it endorsed the motion for "a united and independent Macedonia and a united and independent Thrace" with the perspective of entering into a union within a Balkan federation "against the national and social yoke of the Greek and Bulgarian [[Bourgeois nationalism|bourgeoisie]]".
However, the KKE suffered a crushing defeat it the [[Greek legislative election, 1928|1928 Greek elections]], especially in Greek Macedonia. Dissentions within the KKE had already made the motion untenable by 1927, and in March, the KKE conference watered it down, calling for autodetermination of the Macedonians until they join a "Balkan [[Soviet (council)|Soviet]] Socialist Federation" and only for "a section of Macedonia ([[Florina]] area) inhabited by Slavomacedonians<ref>(Holevas 1992). At the time the term "Slavomacedonian" was not considered offensive: the ''[[Greek Helsinki Monitor]]'' reports that the term, "was accepted by the community itself". However, today the term has pejorative connotations.</ref>" By 1935, it simply called for "equal rights to all" due to the "change of the national composition of the Greek part of Macedonia" and hence because "the [[Leninism|Leninist]]–[[Stalinism|Stalinist]] principle of self-determination demands the substitution of the old slogan". The KPJ had its own problems and dissentions; fears of [[Serbianisation]] of the party and of the [[Vardar Banovina]], whose inhabitants felt closer (though not necessarily identified) to Bulgaria than the [[Kingdom of Yugoslavia]]. The KPJ followed the KKE example in 1936. In 1936 the left wings of the IMRO, ITRO, and IDRO were incorporated by regional principle into the Balkan Communist Parties.
In [[Albania]], Communist ideas were mainly infiltrated by adjacent countries. Despite the effort of the Comintern to establish a Communist Party by sending and supporting emissaries as [[Kosta Boshnjaku]] and [[Ali Kelmendi]] later, Communist groups were not well organized, and they were weak. The Communist Party would be established only in 1941. Nevertheless, the contacts of the Albanians with Comintern were set way before. The [[Paris Peace Conference, 1919|Paris Peace Conference]] had fixed the borders of Albania as defined pre-[[World War I]] by the [[London Conference of 1912–13]], leaving substantial Albanian-populated areas outside of its borders. At the same time, the country was dominated by during the early 1920s by an [[Ottoman Empire|Ottoman]] ruling class with no intention of addressing the country's sharp topics, including an agrarian reform and the fate of the Albanians left outside the borders.
In the early 1920s, two entities came in contact with the Comintern: the left-wing opposition led by Bishop [[Fan Noli]], and the [[Committee of Kosovo]]. [[Bajram Curri]], a [[Kosovar Albanian]] and key person of both, said in December 1921 to the Soviet minister in [[Vienna]] that "the Albanian people await impatiently the determination of their frontiers not on the basis of brutal and bloody historical considerations, but rather on the basis of the situation which actually exists today. With the firm conviction that Soviet Russia will be able in the near future to determine the boundaries of Europe, especially in the Balkans, in a just manner, I pray that the great Soviet government will grant our just requests at that time."<ref>Pano, Nicholas C. ''The People's Republic of Albania''. Baltimore, MD: The Johns Hopkins Press. 1968. pp. 27–28.</ref>
After the failed [[June Revolution]], Noli and others settled in Vienna where they formed [[KONARE]] (Revolutionary National Committee), a left-wing revolutionary committee openly pro-Soviet. Though KONARE, but even by themselves, the Committee of Kosovo would join the Balkan Federation and receive financial support.<ref name="Banac">{{cite book| url=https://books.google.com/books?id=KfqbujXqQBkC&pg=PA305 | author=Ivo Banac| title=The National Question in Yugoslavia: Origins, History, Politics| isbn= 978-0-8014-9493-2| publisher=Cornell University Press | year=1988|pages=305–306}}</ref><ref>{{citation |last1=Vllamasi |first1=Sejfi |last2 =Verli |first2 =Marenglen |title=Ballafaqime Politike në Shqipëri (1897–1942): Kujtime dhe Vlerësime Historike |year=2000 |location= Tirana| publisher =Shtëpia Botuese "Neraida"|isbn=99927-713-1-3 |url= https://books.google.com/books?id=9aC4AAAAIAAJ| quote=Një pjesë me rëndësi e emigrantëve, me inisiativën dhe ndërmjetësinë e Koço Boshnjakut, u muarrën vesh me "Cominternin", si grup, me emër "KONARE" (Komiteti Revolucionar Kombëtar), për t'u ndihmuar pa kusht gjatë aktivitetit të tyre nacional, ashtu siç janë ndihmuar edhe kombet e tjerë të vegjël, që ndodheshin nën zgjedhë të imperialistëve, për liri e për pavarësi. Përveç kësaj pjese, edhe emigrantët kosovarë irredentistë, të grupuar e të organizuar nën emrin "Komiteti i Kosovës", si grup, u ndihmuan edhe ata nga "Cominterni".}}</ref> They would cooperate with IMRO revolutionaries as [[Todor Aleksandrov]] and [[Petar Chaulev]].<ref name="shqip">{{citation|language=Albanian|publisher=Gazeta Shqip Online| accessdate=2014-12-04 |url=http://gazeta-shqip.com/lajme/2012/10/13/zija-dibra-te-fshehtat-e-nje-vrasjeje/|title=Zija Dibra: Të fshehtat e një vrasjeje| date=2012-10-13| author=Fatos Baxhaku| quote=Çaulev kishte takuar Hasan Prishtinën, ndërsa Aleksandrov Bajram Currin. Zija Dibra, madje u akuzua nga jugosllavët edhe si organizator i një takimi Noli-Aleksandrov, por ky takim u përgënjeshtrua nga Tirana zyrtare. Brenda pak muajsh, agjentët jugosllavë arritën të vrasin krerët e VMRO, Aleksandrovin në gusht të 1924 dhe Çaulevin, në dhjetor të 1924 teksa e kishin ndjekur deri në Milano, pas kthimit të tij nga Shqipëria.}}</ref> By 1928, KONARE came de facto under the control of the Comintern; 24 young Albanians were sent to Moscow to study in Soviet institutions.<ref>{{cite book| url=https://books.google.com/books?id=vTZnAAAAMAAJ&&pg=PA122 | author=Bernd Jürgen Fischer|title=Albania at War, 1939–1945| publisher= Purdue University Press| location= West Lafayette, Ind.| year=1999|isbn=978-0-585-06388-1 | series= Central European studies|oclc=42922446|page=122}}</ref> But by the early 1930s, the defense of Yugoslavia became an official Communist line. This way any support for the Committee of Kosovo faded. The introduction of [[Italian Fascism|Fascist Italy]]'s interests in the equation completely disrupted any connection between Albanian nationalist-irredentist movements and the Comintern.<ref name="Banac"/> KONARE would also dissolve in the mid-1930s, leaving the Comintern with few scattered communists groups within Albania.
== Cominform period (1946–1948) ==
For a short period during the [[Cominform]], the Yugoslav and Bulgarian Communist leaders [[Josip Broz Tito]] and [[Georgi Dimitrov]] worked on a project to merge their two countries into a Balkan Federative Republic. As a concession to the Yugoslavian side, Bulgarian authorities agreed to the recognition of a distinct Macedonian ethnicity and language in part of their own population in the Bulgarian part of geographical Macedonia. This was one of the conditions of the [[Bled Agreement (1947)|Bled Agreement]], signed between Yugoslavia and Bulgaria on 1 August 1947. In November 1947, pressured by both the Yugoslavs and the Soviets, Bulgaria also signed a treaty of friendship with Yugoslavia.<ref name=autogenerated1>Niel Simpson, Macedonia; Its Disputed History, Aristoc Press. 1994</ref><ref name="Pedro" /> The Bulgarian president Georgi Dimitrov was sympathetic to the [[Macedonian Question]].<ref name="Simpson">{{cite book | last =Neil | first =Simpson | title =Macedonia; Its disputed history | publisher =Aristoc Press | year =1994 | page =89 | isbn =0-646-20462-9}}</ref> The Bulgarian Communist party was compelled once again to adapt its stand to Soviet interests in the Balkans.<ref name="Pedro">{{cite book | last =Ramet | first =Pedro | title =Religion and Nationalism in Soviet and East European Politics | publisher =Duke University Press | year =1989 | page =374 | isbn =0-8223-0891-6}}</ref> The policies resulting from the agreement were reversed after the [[Tito–Stalin split]] in June 1948, when Bulgaria, being subordinated to Soviet interests, was forced to take a stance against Yugoslavia.<ref>Stavrianos, L. (1964)</ref>
== See also == * [[Balkanization]] * [[Balkan League]] (1912) * [[Balkan Pact]] (1934) * [[Balkan Pact (1953)]] * [[Balkan sprachbund]] * [[Balkania (proposed state)|Balkania]]

No. 1], July 1915. * [[Yanko Sakazov|Janko Sakasoff]], [https://www.marxists.org/history/etol/revhist/otherdox/balk/sakasoff.htm ''Neoslavism, Balkan Federation and Social Democracy''], "Der Kampf", IV, 5, 1 February 1911.

revision.text:
{{Infobox military unit | unit_name = Comando Operacional do Continente
''COPCON'' | image = File:COPCON Insignia.png | caption = | dates = 1974–1975 | country = [[flag|Portugal]] | countries = | allegiance = [[Armed Forces Movement]] | branch = [[Portuguese Army|Army]] | type = | role = | size = | command_structure = | garrison = | garrison_label = | nickname = | patron = | motto = | colors = | colors_label = | march = | mascot = | equipment = | equipment_label = | battles = [[Coup of 25 November 1975]] | anniversaries = 8 July | decorations = | battle_honours = | battle_honours_label = | disbanded = 1975 | flying_hours = | website = | commander1 = Major [[Otelo Saraiva de Carvalho]] | commander1_label = Commander | commander2 = | commander2_label = | notable_commanders = | identification_symbol = | identification_symbol_label = | identification_symbol_2 = | identification_symbol_2_label = | identification_symbol_3 = | identification_symbol_3_label = | identification_symbol_4 = | identification_symbol_4_label = }} '''COPCON - Comando Operacional do Continente''' (Operational Command of the Continent) was a military command for [[Portugal]] created by the [[Armed Forces Movement]] in the period following the [[Carnation Revolution|revolution of 25 April 1974]] and was dissolved after the [[Coup of 25 November 1975]].{{cite web|url=http://www.cmjornal.xl.pt/domingo/detalhe/presos-400-militantes-do-mrpp.html|title=Presos 400 militantes do MRPP - Domingo - Correio da Manhã|website=cmjornal.xl.pt|accessdate=2018-01-20}} COPCON was created on July 8, 1974 {{cite web|url=http://www1.ci.uc.pt/cd25a/wikka.php?wakka=extinc07|title=Centro de Documentação 25 de Abril | Universidade de Coimbra|website=www1.ci.uc.pt|accessdate=2018-01-20}}https://dre.pt/application/dir/pdf1s%5c1974%5c07%5c15702%5c00170018.pdf by President [[António de Spínola]], with the aim of protecting the democratic process initiated by the Carnation Revolution. It consisted of special military forces such as [[Portuguese Marine Corps|marines]], [[Portuguese Paratroopers|paratroopers]], [[Portuguese Army Commandos|commandos]], military police. The commander of COPCON was Major [[Otelo Saraiva de Carvalho]]. COPCON was heavily involved in the land occupations and agrarian reform during the [[Processo Revolucionário Em Curso|PREC]].Hammond, John L. Building popular power: Workers' and neighborhood movements in the Portuguese revolution. Monthly Review Press, 1988.“Scenes from the Class Struggle in Portugal = Cenas Da Luta De Classes Em Portugal.” New York Cinema Co., 1976. ==References== {{Reflist}} [[Category:Carnation Revolution]] [[Category:Portuguese Army]] {{Portugal-stub}}

revision.text:
{{italic title}} [[Image:Tlaloc, Codex Rios, p.20r.JPG|thumb|right|A painting of [[Tlaloc]], as shown on page 20R of Codex Ríos.]] '''''Codex Ríos''''' is an Italian translation and augmentation of a Spanish colonial-era manuscript, [[Codex Telleriano-Remensis]], that is partially attributed to Pedro de los Ríos, a [[Dominican Order|Dominican]] [[Dominican friar|friar]] working in Oaxaca and Puebla between 1547 and 1562. The [[codex]] itself was likely written and drawn in Italy after 1566.
The manuscript is focused on the [[Tolteca-Chichimeca]] culture in the Tehuacan Valley in modern-day [[Puebla]] and [[Oaxaca]]. It can be divided into seven sections:<ref>{{citeweb| url=http://www.famsi.org/research/graz/vaticanus3738/|title=FAMSI - Akademische Druck - u. Verlagsanstalt - Graz - Codex Vaticanus 3738| website=Akademische Druck - u. Verlagsanstalt - Graz CODICES |publisher=[[FAMSI]]|accessdate=29 July 2014}}</ref>
:# Cosmological and mythological traditions with emphasis on the four epochs. :# An almanac, or ''[[tonalamatl]]'', for the 260-day divinatory year common in [[Mesoamerica]]. :# Calendar tables for the years 1558 through 1619, without drawings. :# An 18-month festival calendar, with drawings of the gods of each period. :# Ritual customs, with portraits of Indians. :# Pictorial chronicles for the years 1195-1549 beginning with the migration from [[Chicomoztoc]] and covering later events in the [[Valley of Mexico]]. :# Glyphs for the years 1556 through 1562, without drawings or text.
''Codex Ríos'' consists of 101 pages of European paper, accordion-folded. It is held in the [[Vatican Library]], Rome, and is also variously known as '''Codex Vatican A''', '''Codex Vaticanus A''', and '''Codex Vaticanus 3738'''.
Facsimile: Codex Vaticanus A (3738), Rome, Bibliotheca Apostolica Vaticana, around 1580; Akademische Druck- u. Verlagsanstalt (ADEVA) Graz 1979. Colour reproduction for studies of the manuscript in possession of the Bibliotèca Apostolica Vaticana, reduced to 7/10 of the original size, i.e. to 340 x 260 mm. Miniature paintings with Italian notes. Half leather binding. Introduction: Akademische Druck- u. Verlagsanstalt. 14 pp. and 192 plates. CODICES SELECTI, Vol. LXV
==References== {{reflist}}
==Gallery== <gallery> Image:Centeotl.jpg|[[Centeotl]] Image:Chalchiutlicue rios.jpg|[[Chalchiuhtlicue]] Image:Mayahuel 1.jpg|[[Mayahuel]] Image:Patecatl.jpg|[[Patecatl]] Image:Tepeyollotl 1.jpg|[[Tepeyollotl]] Image:Tlaloc, Codex Rios, p.20r.JPG|[[Tlaloc]] Image:Xochiquetzal.jpg|[[Xochiquetzal]] </gallery>
==See also== *[[Codex Vaticanus B]] *[[Mesoamerican codices]] *[[Aztec codices]] *[[Aztec calendar]]
{{DEFAULTSORT:Codex Rios}} [[Category:Astrological texts]] [[Category:Mesoamerican codices|Rios, Codex]] [[Category:Manuscripts of the Vatican Library]]

revision.text:
{{Infobox Union |name= Akava |country= [[Finland]] |affiliation= [[International Trade Union Confederation|ITUC]], [[Council of Nordic Trade Unions|NFS]], [[ETUC]], [[TUAC]] |members= 609,000 (2018) |full_name= Confederation of Unions for Professional and Managerial Staff in Finland |native_name= Finnish: Korkeakoulutettujen työmarkkinakeskusjärjestö Akava; Swedish: Centralorganisationen för högutbildade i Finland Akava |image= |founded= 1950 |current= |head= |dissolved_date= |dissolved_state= |merged_into= |office= [[Helsinki]], Finland |people= [[Sture Fjäder]], president |website= [http://www.akava.fi/en/ www.akava.fi] |footnotes= }} <!-- Include all unused fields for future use. See [[template talk:Infobox Union]] for usage. -->
The '''Confederation of Unions for Professional and Managerial Staff in Finland'''<ref>Previously named ''Confederation of Unions for Academic Professionals in Finland''</ref> ('''Akava''') is a [[trade union]] confederation in [[Finland]]. It represents employees with university-level, professional or other high-level training. It has a membership of 609,000.
Akava is a [[central organization]] i.e. the individual members are not personally members of Akava but of a [[trade union]] which is a member of Akava. Akava has 36 member unions, the largest of which are the [[Trade Union of Education in Finland]] (OAJ), the [[Finnish Association of Graduate Engineers]] (TEK), the [[Union of Professional Engineers in Finland]] UIL), the [[Finnish Association of Business School Graduates]] (SEFE) and [[w:fi:Tradenomiliitto|Tradenomiliitto]]. On 25 October 2011 Sture Fjäder was elected President of Akava for a four-year term.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.nordiclabourjournal.org/artikler/portrett/portrait-2013-1/article.2013-11-05.5953976595/ |title=Sture Fjäder challenges Finland’s trade union culture |last=Lindén |first=Carl-Gustav |date=2013-11-07 |access-date=2018-01-21}}</ref> Akava is affiliated with the [[International Trade Union Confederation]], the [[Council of Nordic Trade Unions]], and the [[European Trade Union Confederation]].
Akava is one of the three central organizations representing Finnish employees, the other two being the [[Finnish Confederation of Salaried Employees]] (STTK) and the [[Central Organisation of Finnish Trade Unions]] (SAK).
==External links== * [http://www.akava.fi/en/ Akava's website in English]
==References== <references/> {{Portal|Organized labour}}

revision.text:
{{Infobox anthem |title = Gibraltar Anthem |transcription = |english_title = |alt_title = |en_alt_title = |alt_title_2 = |en_alt_title_2 = |image = |image_size = |caption = |prefix = Territorial |country = {{flag|Gibraltar}} |author = [[Peter Emberley]] |lyrics_date = 1994 |composer = Peter Emberley |music_date = 1994 |adopted = 18 October 1994 |sound = |sound_title = }} The '''''Gibraltar Anthem''''' is the [[national song]] of the [[British overseas territories|British overseas territory]] of [[Gibraltar]].
In common with the [[United Kingdom]], [[Crown dependencies]] and other British territories, the official national anthem of Gibraltar is [[God Save the Queen]]. The Gibraltar anthem is the national song, and was chosen in a competition in 1994. Both the [[lyrics]] and [[music]] were composed by [[Peter Emberley]], who is not a [[Gibraltarian people|Gibraltarian]].
The anthem is sung every 10 September by the general public at the annual release of 30,000 [[Flag of Gibraltar|red and white]] [[balloon]]s on [[Gibraltar National Day]].
==Lyrics== <poem>Gibraltar, Gibraltar, The Rock on which I stand, May you be forever free, Gibraltar, my own land.
Mighty pillar, Rock of splendour, Guardian of the sea, Port of hope in times of need, Rich in history.
Gibraltar, Gibraltar, The Rock on which I stand, May you be forever free, Gibraltar my own land.
God give grace to this our homeland, Help us to live as one, Strong in freedom, Truth and justice, Let this be our song.
Gibraltar, Gibraltar, The Rock on which I stand, May you be forever free, Gibraltar! Gibraltar! My own land!</poem>
==See also== * [[Llévame Donde Nací]] * [[Bardengesang auf Gibraltar: O Calpe! Dir donnert's am Fuße]]
==External links== *[http://www.gibnet.com/gib.mid Midi arrangement] *{{YouTube|M4gZOidhxtA|Instrumental}}

[[File:The Fleet Messenger 'isonzo' at Malta - off the Castile (signal Station) Art.IWMART3120.jpg|thumb|300px|Painting of a Gozo boat in the [[Grand Harbour]] during [[World War I]]]]
The '''Gozo boat''' ({{lang-mt|Dgħajsa ta’ Għawdex, tal-latini, tat-tagħbija, tal-pass}} or {{lang|mt|tal-mogħdija}}) was a type of [[Settee (sail)|settee]]-rigged boat originating from [[Malta]]. Gozo boats were the main means of transport across the [[Gozo Channel]] between [[Gozo]] and the [[Malta (island)|main island of Malta]]<ref name="morana">{{cite book|last1=Morana|first1=Martin|title=Bejn Kliem u Storja|date=2011|publisher=Books Distributors Limited|location=[[Malta]]|isbn=978-99957-0137-6|url=https://sites.google.com/site/kliemustorja/home/titlu/introduzzjoni/dwar-l-awtur/a/b/c/c/d|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20161005162338/https://sites.google.com/site/kliemustorja/home/titlu/introduzzjoni/dwar-l-awtur/a/b/c/c/d|archivedate=5 October 2016|language=Maltese}}</ref> from at least 1241 to the 1960s.
==History== [[File:Malta Gozo boat-2-6.jpg|thumb|Gozo boat on a 1926 Maltese stamp]]
Gozo boats evolved from the speronara ({{lang-mt|xprunara}}), which was found all over the [[Mediterranean Sea]].<ref name="morana"/> The oldest records of a transport link between Gozo and Malta date back to 1241, when the boat was known as a ''dgħajsa tal-mogħdija'' or ''tal-pass''. By the 16th century, Gozo boats took the shape of a [[brigantine]]. In the 1880s, many Gozo boats changed their sail arrangements to a [[Settee (sail)|settee]] rig. In 1919, engines began to be installed on some Gozo boats, although many still retained their sails.<ref name=gozochannel>{{cite web|last1=Muscat|first1=Joseph|title=The Gozo boat|url=http://www.gozochannel.com/gozoboat.htm|website=Gozo Channel Co. Ltd.|publisher=Fondazzjoni Patrimonju Malti|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120303053346/http://www.gozochannel.com/gozoboat.htm|archivedate=3 March 2012|date=1999}}</ref>
Most Gozo boats were built at [[Kalkara]] in the [[Grand Harbour]]. The Caruana family, who were the last builders of Gozo boats, moved from there to [[Mġarr, Gozo|Mġarr]] on Gozo in 1940. After 1959, a few Gozo boats were built in [[Gela]], [[Sicily]]. The last one to be built was the ''Santa Rita'' (G48) in 1963.<ref name=gozochannel/>
Gozo boats usually made trips from the Grand Harbour in Malta to Mġarr Harbour on Gozo. Other trips were made from the Grand Harbour to [[Mellieħa]] or to Marfa, or Mġarr to Marfa or [[St. Paul's Bay]]. The boats carried both passengers and cargo between the two islands. Trips from Gozo to Malta were generally loaded with agricultural products such as fruit, vegetables, eggs and poultry, while return trips from Malta to Gozo were loaded with manufactured goods such as cement, soft drinks and beer.<ref name=letsgozo/>
Gozo boats were painted in shades of green, blue, red and yellow, similar to the traditional ''[[luzzu]]''. One boat was painted black to carry corpses between the islands.<ref name=letsgozo>{{cite journal|title=Rites of passage|journal=Let's Gozo|date=June 2007|pages=16-17|url=http://www.wirtghawdex.org/news/media-articles/156-2007-rites-of-passage-let-s-gozo/file|accessdate=25 July 2015}}</ref>
===Accidents=== There were a number of accidents involving Gozo boats. Some were hit by rifle fire while passing the [[Pembroke, Malta|Pembroke]] Rifle Ranges, although the authorities warned the boats' masters in advance. In 1900, a Gozo boat used that was being used for ''[[Mahi-mahi|lampuki]]'' fishing capsized, killing one fisherman. Another boat lost her masts in 1911, but it managed to enter St. George's Bay. In 1926, an unoccupied Gozo boat was found adrift in rough seas. In rare cases, they were involved in collisions with [[tugboat]]s or [[Pinnace (ship's boat)|pinnaces]].<ref name=gozochannel/>
In [[World War II]], the boat ''Stella Maris'' was destroyed by enemy action.
===Decline=== By the 1960s and 1970s, regular steamer services began to compete with the Gozo boats, which were no longer suitable for the changing socio-economic situation. The remaining boats were converted into fishing boats, or were abandoned at Mġarr Harbour.<ref name=gozochannel/>
Since 1979, the Gozo ferry service has been operated by [[Gozo Channel Line|Gozo Channel Company Limited]], which now uses modern [[Roll-on/roll-off|RORO ferries]].<ref>{{cite web|title=History|url=http://www.gozochannel.com/en/history.htm|website=Gozo Channel Co. Ltd.|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150329140913/http://gozochannel.com/en/history.htm|archivedate=29 March 2015}}</ref>
==Surviving examples== [[File:Malta - Sliema (Triq Ix-Xatt (Gzira)) 09 ies.jpg|thumb|''Maryanne'']]
Very few Gozo boats still survive today.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Dougall|first1=Angelo|title=The Gozo Boat - Extinction of a breed|journal=L-Imnara|date=August 1983|volume=2|issue=1|pages=13-15|url=http://melitensiawth.com/incoming/Index/L-Imnara/L-Imnara.%2002(1983)1=6/10s.pdf|accessdate=25 July 2015|publisher=Għaqda tal-Folklor}}</ref> One of these is the ''Sacra Famiglia'' (G32), which was built in [[Kalkara]] in 1933.<ref>{{cite news|title=Id-Dgħajsa Tal-Latini to dominate Mġarr Harbour again|url=http://www.independent.com.mt/articles/2011-08-08/news/id-dg-and-295ajsa-tal-latini-to-dominate-m-and-289arr-harbour-again-296889/|accessdate=25 July 2015|work=[[The Malta Independent]]|date=8 August 2011}}</ref> It had become unseaworthy by the 1970s, and was beached at [[Mġarr, Gozo|Mġarr]]. The hulk was eventually purchased by a private individual who wanted to sell it to the Ministry for Gozo. It was then purchased by the [[Gozo Channel Line|Gozo Channel Company Limited]], who handed it to [[Wirt Għawdex]] and sponsored its restoration. After the boat was restored by the Caruana brothers (the sons of its original builder), it was placed on permanent display at the Żewwieqa promenade in 2014.<ref>{{cite web|title=Dgħajsa Tal-Latini|url=http://www.wirtghawdex.org/component/k2/dg%C4%A7ajsa-tal-latini|website=[[Wirt Għawdex]]|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150725142320/http://www.wirtghawdex.org/component/k2/dg%C4%A7ajsa-tal-latini|archivedate=25 July 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=‘Dghajsa Tal-Latini’ fully restored & on display at the Zewwieqa Waterfront|url=http://gozonews.com/53284/dghajsa-tal-latini-fully-restored-on-display-at-the-zewwieqa-waterfront/|accessdate=25 July 2015|work=Gozo News|date=2 November 2014}}</ref>
Another surviving Gozo boat is the ''Maryanne'', which was built in Gela in 1960. The boat remained in Gozo until February 1983, when it was purchased by Captain Morgan Cruises. The boat still belongs to Captain Morgan, and it is used for cruises around [[Marsamxett Harbour|Marsamxett]] and the [[Grand Harbour]]. ''Maryanne'' is in good condition, but it no longer has the distinctive masts and a deck has been added.<ref>{{cite web|title=Maryanne |url=http://www.captainmorgan.com.mt/maryanne |website=Captain Morgan Cruises |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131027092831/http://www.captainmorgan.com.mt/maryanne |archivedate=27 October 2013 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref>
Another two or three Gozo boats which were converted into fishing boats might still exist.<ref name=gozochannel/>
==Legacy== [[File:MLT Qala COA.gif|right|Coat of arms of Qala]]
The Gozo boat has become a symbol of the island of Gozo,<ref>{{cite web|title=Gozo|url=http://www.gozoandmalta.com/gozo.php|website=gozoandmalta.com|accessdate=25 July 2015}}</ref> and a boat sailing on rough waters is featured on the flag and coat of arms of the village of [[Qala, Malta|Qala]].<ref>{{cite web|title=About Qala|url=http://www.stampworld.com/en/|website=Qala Local Council|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110408090112/http://www.qala.gov.mt/default.asp?module=content&pageid=124|archivedate=8 April 2011}}</ref> Gozo boats are also found in the logos of various Gozitan organizations, such as the Gozo Philatelic Society<ref>{{cite web|title=About Us|url=https://www.stamps-gozo.org/about-us.html|website=Gozo Philatelic Society|accessdate=25 July 2015}}</ref> and the Imperial Gozo Yacht Club.<ref>{{cite news|title=Imperial Gozo Yacht Club opens new premises at Mgarr|url=http://gozonews.com/1485/imperial-gozo-yacht-club-opens-new-premises-at-mgarr/|accessdate=25 July 2015|work=Gozo News|date=24 October 2007}}</ref>
The classical 1970s song ''Id-Dgħajsa tal-Latini'' by the Maltese band New Cuorey is about a Gozo boat.<ref name=dictionary>{{cite book|last1=Schiavone|first1=Michael J.|title=Dictionary of Maltese Biographies Vol. 1 A-F|date=2009|publisher=Pubblikazzjonijiet Indipendenza|location=[[Pietà, Malta|Pietà]]|isbn=9789993291329|page=189}}</ref>
==Further reading== *[http://melitensiawth.com/incoming/Index/Melita%20Historica/MH.13(2000-03)/MH.13(2003)4/06.pdf Graffiti]
==References== {{reflist|30em}} {{commons category}}

revision.comment: Adding [[Wikipedia:Short description|short description]]: "An area of mainly sea to the south of the South Island of New Zealand" ([[User:Galobtter/Shortdesc helper|Shortdesc helper]])
revision.text:
{{short description|An area of mainly sea to the south of the South Island of New Zealand}} [[Image:GreatSouthBasinNZ.PNG|thumb|right|Approximate location of the Great South Basin with approximate location of allocated Oil Exploration Blocks]]
The '''Great South Basin''' is an area of mainly sea to the south of the [[South Island]] of [[New Zealand]].
Starting in the 1960s, the area was explored and drilled for oil deposits by various, mostly international minerals companies — including [[Hunt Oil]] — but by 1984 all of these companies had left empty-handed.<ref>[http://www.crownminerals.govt.nz/cms/pdf-library/petroleum-basins-1/gsb-media-pack/GSB%20Timeline.pdf Crown Minerals - Great South Basin Timeline]</ref>
With advances in seismic surveying and drilling technology, hopes have been raised once again for a potential oil strike. Since 2006, new tenders for drilling rights have been issued.<ref>[http://www.scoop.co.nz/stories/PA0607/S00547.htm Bidding opens for oil and gas in Great South Basin]</ref>
In 2010, [[Exxon Mobil]] and [[Todd Energy]] relinquished their exploration rights, citing technical difficulties and the harshness of the environment.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.nzherald.co.nz/business/news/article.cfm?c_id=3&objectid=10679766 |title=Exxon Mobil abandons Great South Basin|publisher=New Zealand Herald|date=11 October 2010}}</ref> [[Royal Dutch Shell]] subsequently purchased a stake in a joint venture headed by [[OMV]] New Zealand,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.stuff.co.nz/business/industries/5453456/ |title=Shell-joins-southern-oil-hunt Shell joins southern oil hunt |publisher=BusinessDay.co.nz |date=16 August 2011}}</ref> with drilling announced at the start of 2014.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.stuff.co.nz/business/industries/9584446/Shell-proceeds-with-Great-South-Basin-drilling|title=Shell proceeds with Great South Basin drilling|date=2014-01-07|publisher=Fairfax Media}}</ref> [[Anadarko Petroleum Corporation]] made a test drilling in the area in early 2014, without success.<ref name=anadarko>{{cite news|url=http://www.radionz.co.nz/news/national/257767/greenpeace-hits-out-at-prospect-plan|title=Greenpeace hits out at prospect plan|date=2014-10-25|publisher=Radio New Zealand}}</ref> [[Schlumberger]] subsequently made a drilling attempt in the same areas later in the year.<ref name=anadarko />
==References==
{{reflist}}
==External links== * [https://web.archive.org/web/20070929061710/http://oilgasmineralsnz.com/oilgasminerals/GreatSouthBasin Oil,Gas & Minerals Of Southland, New Zealand] * [http://www.crownminerals.govt.nz/cms/about/media-centre/great-south-basin-media-pack-1/great-south-basin-questions-and-answers Crown Minerals Group - Ministry of Economic Development] * [https://wikileaks.org/cable/2006/07/06WELLINGTON551.html WikiLeaks Cable 06WELLINGTON551, NEW ZEALAND MAY SEE BIGGER HUNT FOR OIL AND GAS]

1996 |area_rank = |area_magnitude = |area_km2 = 5,204,977 |area_sq_mi = 1,997,303 |population_estimate = |population_estimate_rank = |population_estimate_year = |population_density_km2 = |population_density_sq_mi = |population_density_rank = |GDP_PPP =$337.82 billion |GDP_PPP_rank = |GDP_PPP_year = |GDP_PPP_per_capita = |GDP_PPP_per_capita_rank = |GDP_nominal =$197.202 billion |GDP_nominal_rank = |GDP_nominal_year = |GDP_nominal_per_capita =$888.5 |GDP_nominal_per_capita_rank = |Gini_year = |Gini_change = |Gini = |Gini_ref = |Gini_rank = |HDI_year = |HDI_change = |HDI = |HDI_ref = |HDI_rank = |currency = |time_zone = [[East Africa Time]] |utc_offset = +3 |official_website = {{URL|www.igad.org}} }} The '''Intergovernmental Authority on Development''' ('''IGAD''') is an eight-country [[trade bloc]] in [[Africa]]. It includes governments from the [[Horn of Africa]], [[Nile Valley]] and the [[African Great Lakes]]. Its headquarters are in [[Djibouti (city)|Djibouti City]]. ==Member states== ;Horn of Africa *{{flag|Djibouti}} (founding member, since 1986) *{{flag|Ethiopia}} (founding member, since 1986) *{{flag|Somalia}} (founding member, since 1986) *{{flag|Eritrea}} (admitted 1993, withdrew 2007, readmitted 2011){{cite web |title=Intergovernmental Authority on Development: About us: History |first= |last= |publisher=IGAD |date=9 January 2010 |url=http://www.igad.org/ |accessdate=29 December 2014}} ;Nile Valley *{{flag|Sudan}} (founding member, since 1986) *{{flag|South Sudan}} (admitted 2011){{cite web |title=East African bloc admits South Sudan as member |first= |last= |publisher=Reuters Africa |date=25 November 2011 |url=https://af.reuters.com/article/investingNews/idAFJOE7AO0A820111125 |accessdate=25 October 2012}} ;African Great Lakes *{{flag|Kenya}} (founding member, since 1986) *{{flag|Uganda}} (founding member, since 1986) ==Formation== The Intergovernmental Authority on Development was established in 1996. It succeeded the earlier Intergovernmental Authority on Drought and Development (IGADD), a multinational body founded in 1986 by Djibouti, Ethiopia, Somalia, Sudan, Uganda and Kenya, with a focus on development and environmental control. IGADD's headquarters were later moved to Djibouti, following an agreement signed in January 1986 by the member states. Eritrea joined the organization in 1993, upon achieving independence.{{cite web|title=IGAD - About us|url=http://www.igad.int/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=93&Itemid=124|publisher=Intergovernmental Authority on Development|accessdate=25 August 2013}} In April 1995, the Assembly of Heads of State and Government met in [[Addis Ababa]], where they agreed to strengthen cooperation through the organization. This was followed with the signing of a Letter of Instrument to Amend the IGADD Charter / Agreement on 21 March 1996. The Revitalised IGAD, a new organizational structure, was eventually launched on 25 November 1996 in Djibouti. ==IGASOM/AMISOM== {{Politics of the African Union mini|financial|width=5em}} {{main|AMISOM}} In September 2006, the AU Peace and Security Council approved an IGAD proposal to deploy an IGAD Peace Support Mission in Somalia (IGASOM).{{cite news|title=SOMALIA: African Union endorses regional peace plan|url=http://ports.co.za/news/article_2006_09_15_3438.html#five|accessdate=25 August 2013|newspaper=IRIN|date=14 September 2006}} On 21 February 2007, the [[United Nations Security Council]] approved Resolution 1744, which authorized the deployment of a new [[African Union Mission to Somalia]] (AMISOM) in place of IGASOM.{{cite web|title=Resolution 1744 (2007)|url=http://www.treasury.gov/resource-center/sanctions/Documents/1744.pdf|publisher=United Nations Security Council|accessdate=25 August 2013}} ==Current situation== *IGAD is a principal supporter of the [[Federal Government of Somalia]] through the AMISOM initiative. *IGAD expanded its activities in 2008 with initiatives to improve the investment, trade and banking environments of member states. The organization stressed the deployment of highly innovative programmes and mechanisms. ==Structure== *The '''Assembly of Heads of State and Government''' is the supreme policy making organ of the Authority. It determines the objectives, guidelines and programs for IGAD and meets once a year. A Chairman is elected from among the member states in rotation. *The '''Secretariat''' is headed by an Executive Secretary appointed by the Assembly of Heads of State and Government for a term of four years renewable once. The Secretariat assists member states in formulating regional projects in the priority areas, facilitates the coordination and harmonization of development policies, mobilizes resources to implement regional projects and programs approved by the Council and reinforces national infrastructures necessary for implementing regional projects and policies. The current Executive Secretary is Eng. Mahboub Maalim of Kenya (since 14 June 2008). *The '''Council of Ministers''' is composed of the Ministers of Foreign Affairs and one other Minister designated by each member state. The Council formulates policy, approves the work program and annual budget of the Secretariat during its biannual sessions. *The '''Committee of Ambassadors''' comprises IGAD member states' Ambassadors or Plenipotentiaries accredited to the country of IGAD Headquarters. It convenes as often as the need arises to advise and guide the Executive Secretary. ==Comparison with other regional trade blocs== {{African Economic Community}} ==See also== *[[East African Community]] (EAC) *[[Common Market for Eastern and Southern Africa]] (COMESA) ==Notes== {{Reflist}} ==External links== *[http://www.igad.org/ IGAD official site] *[http://www.igad.org/about/agreement_establishing_igad.pdf Agreement Establishing the Intergovernmental Authority on Development] *[http://www.iss.co.za/AF/RegOrg/unity_to_union/igadprof.htm IGAD Profile (Institute for Security Studies)] *[http://www.cewarn.org/ Conflict Early Warning and Response Mechanism (CEWARN)] {{African Trade Agreements}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Intergovernmental Authority On Development}} [[Category:Politics of Africa]] [[Category:Regional Economic Communities of the African Union]] [[Category:African Union]] [[Category:Trade blocs]] [[Category:1986 establishments in Africa]]

{{Orphan|date=June 2016}} {{Infobox scientist | name = Irene Schloss | image = Irene_InnerPC_2016.jpg | caption = Irene Schloss at [[Carlini Base]] | image_size = 250px | birth_name = | nationality = [[Argentina]] | fields = [[Plankton|Plankton biology]] | workplaces = [[Argentine Antarctic Institute]]
[[National Scientific and Technical Research Council]] - Argentina
[[University of Quebec]] | alma_mater = [[University of Buenos Aires]] | website = [http://www.ismer.ca/Schloss-Irene-R?lang=en Irene Schloss at the University of Quebec] }} '''Irene R. Schloss''' is an [[Antarctic]] researcher, best known for her work on plankton biology. She is a researcher at the [[Instituto Antártico Argentino|Argentine Antarctic Institute]] and is a correspondent researcher of the [[National Scientific and Technical Research Council|National Scientific and Technical Research Council of Argentina,]]{{Cite web|url=http://www.ismer.ca/Schloss-Irene-R?lang=fr|title=Schloss, Irene R. - Institut des sciences de la mer de Rimouski|website=www.ismer.ca|access-date=2016-06-14}} and an associate professor at the [[University of Quebec]]. ==Early life and education== Schloss was born in [[Buenos Aires]], Argentina, where she first completed her “[[Licentiate (degree)|Licenciatura]]” (equivalent to a MSc) in Biology at the [[University of Buenos Aires]]. In 1989 she undertook a fellowship for 6 months ([[International Association for the Exchange of Students for Technical Experience|IAESTE]] and DAAD) at the [[Alfred Wegener Institute for Polar and Marine Research|Alfred-Wegener Institute]] in [[Bremerhaven]], Germany, participating in the international European “Polarstern” Study (EPOS).{{Cite web|url=http://epic.awi.de/26242/|title=The expedition Antarktis VII/3 (EPOS LEG 2) of RV "Polarstern" in 1988/89|last=|first=|date=1989|website=epic.awi.de|publisher=Alfred Wegener Institute|access-date=}} She then began her PhD in 1992 as a National Council of the Research (CONICET) fellow in biological oceanography. Throughout her PhD she studied phytoplankton dynamics in coastal Antarctica. She received her PhD degree from the [[University of Buenos Aires]] in 1997.{{Cite web|url=http://digital.bl.fcen.uba.ar/Download/Tesis/Tesis_2952_Schloss.pdf|title=Escalas temporo-espaciales de variabilidad del fitoplancton costero Antártico|last=Schloss|first=Irene|date=1997|website=|publisher=Universidad de Buenos Aires|trans-title=Temporo-spatial scales of variability in Antarctic coastal phytoplankton|type=Thesis|access-date=}} Between 2005 and 2007, she was a post-doctoral fellow at ISMER, where she studied the dynamics of phytoplankton and physical – biological coupling in the [[Beaufort Sea]] ([[Northern Canada|Canadian Arctic]]). ==Career and impact== Schloss is a researcher at the Argentinian Antarctic Institute (IAA) and is a Correspondent Researcher of the National Council of the Research (CONICET) of Argentina. She has been an associate professor at [[Université du Québec à Rimouski|UQAR]] since 2009, and was a research assistant there since 2008. Her research focusses on the impact of UVB radiation on plankton communities at a range of latitudes, the role of phytoplankton on CO2 fluxes between the ocean and the atmosphere and the effects of global change on coastal plankton.{{Cite web|url=http://www.ismer.ca/Schloss-Irene-R?lang=fr|title=Schloss, Irene R.|website=www.ismer.ca|publisher=Institut des sciences de la mer de Rimouski|access-date=2016-06-14}} She has research expertise in the dynamics of high latitude marine plankton and variations of plankton communities in space and time. Schloss has participated in nine expeditions to Antarctica (ship-based and on Argentinean stations), spending around 17 months in the sixth continent.{{Cite web|url=http://www.scar.org/srp/ant-era#Carlini16|title=Studying the effect of warming oceans and glacier melting on Antarctic plankton.|last=|first=|website=www.scar.org|publisher=Scientific Committee on Antarctic Research|access-date=2016-06-14}} Her greatest impact has been in research on the interactions the adaptation and effects of plankton to ocean climate change. Her work has modelled physical-biological interactions during bloom dynamics in coastal Antarctica, in particular the equilibrium between warming, glacier melt water and wind-induced physical turbulence in coastal waters. Her work on the role of plankton groups on CO2 dynamics indicated that [[diatoms]] are key contributors to atmospheric CO2 uptake in surface waters, providing a direct link between biodiversity and climate-relevant processes. Additionally, her work demonstrated links between large-scale atmospheric phenomena (e.g. [[Southern Annular Mode]] and [[El Niño Southern Oscillation]]) and local phytoplankton dynamics. Schloss plays a central role in the development of international collaborations in Antarctic research. She has been successful in working in polar science in different countries, such as Argentina, Canada, and Germany through the promotion and participation in numerous international research projects and initiatives, cooperating with researchers from USA, Spain, Belgium, Brazil, Poland, and the UK.{{Cite web|url=http://www.imconet.eu/about-the-project/work-packages/wp-2.html|title=Climate change effects on coastal polar environments and on planktonic communities|website=imconet.eu|publisher=Interdisciplinary Modelling of Climate Change in Coastal Western Antarctica Network|access-date=2016-06-14}} She further participates in the development of the Antarctic Environmental Portal.{{Cite web|url=https://www.environments.aq/information-summaries/vulnerability-of-southern-ocean-biota-to-climate-change/|title=Vulnerability of Southern Ocean biota to climate change|website=www.environments.aq|publisher=Antarctic Environments Portal|access-date=2016-06-14}} She is particularly involved in the promotion of Antarctic science.{{Cite web|url=http://www.scar.org/antera/antera-about|title=Antarctic Thresholds - Ecosystem Resilience and Adaptation|last=|first=|website=www.scar.org|publisher=Scientific Committee on Antarctic Research|access-date=2016-06-14}} She participated at the SCAR Horizon SCAN in 2014.{{Cite web|url=http://www.scar.org/horizonscan/retreat/attendees|title=Horizon Scan Retreat|last=|first=|date=2014|website=www.scar.org|publisher=Scientific Committee on Antarctic Research|access-date=2016-06-14}} ==References== {{Reflist|35em}} ==External links== * [http://www.ismer.ca/Schloss-Irene-R?lang=fr Irene Schloss's webpage] * [https://scholar.google.com.au/citations?user=rrwvxqIAAAAJ&hl=en&oi=ao Irene Schloss] on [[Google scholar]] * [https://www.researchgate.net/profile/Irene_Schloss2 Irene Schloss] on [[ResearchGate]] {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Schloss, Irene}} [[Category:Year of birth missing (living people)]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Argentine women scientists]] [[Category:Antarctic scientists]] [[Category:Women Antarctic scientists]] [[Category:Planktologists]] [[Category:Women biologists]]

{{Other uses|Iskra}} {{more citations needed|date=March 2010}} [[Image:Mednarodni sejem Sodobna elektronika v Ljubljani (8).jpg|thumb|Iskra stand at the 1961 International fair ''Modern electronics'' in [[Ljubljana]]]]
== HISTORY == Iskra developed from the SPRAD and a modest factory in Kranj / Strojne tovarne Kranj, a former subsidiary of the Luftfahrtgerätewerk, Berlin. <ref>{{cite book |last1=Predan |first1=Barbara |last2=Požar |first2=Cvetka |title=Iskra non-aligned design 1946-1990 |date=2009 |publisher=Arhitekturni muzej Ljubljana |location=Ljubljana |isbn=978-961-6669-10-8 |url=http://iskra46-90.com/index.php?option=com_content&view=category&layout=blog&id=3&Itemid=4 |accessdate=10 October 2018}}</ref>
In 1946, [https://sl.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mirjan_Gruden prof. dr. Mirjan Gruden] renamed Strojne tovarne Kranj to Iskra (in Slovenian: Spark) using words: "The factory will develop and grow; from a spark, a flame is born, let our iskra start a flame. As electrical technicians, we are always dealing with sparks in our profession. A spark is a symbol for the start of a process."<ref>{{cite web |last1=Perko |first1=Borut |title=Iskra zapustila Gorenjsko |url=https://www.slovenskenovice.si/novice/slovenija/iskra-zapustila-gorenjsko |website=Slovenske novice |accessdate=16 October 2018}}</ref>
The company, which quickly became synonymous with quality, reliability, and modernity, got its own recognisable symbol. A symbol that most likely originates in marks used by guilds, which guaranteed the origin and control of quality and quantity of products, thus completing the symbolic meaning of the newly-formed brand, which goes beyond the basic concept of the company and acts as a unique reflection of the times.
One year after it was established, Iskra developed its first switch, followed by its first FM antenna, capacitor, and then one of the key milestones in Iskra’s success – establishment of its design department. In 1962, this was the first industrial design department in Yugoslavia. Iskra was very serious about design, considering it a strategic elements, and acted according to the principle that the development constructor and the industrial designer must collaborate closely throughout the product development. The company statute from that year already stated that every product must be of high quality, but also reasonably priced and appropriately aesthetically designed.<ref>{{cite web |title=Iskra's Strategic Milestones |url=https://www.iskra.eu/en/Iskras-Strategic-Milestones/ |website=Iskra.eu |accessdate=16 October 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |last1=Perko |first1=Borut |title=Iskra zapustila Gorenjsko |url=https://www.slovenskenovice.si/novice/slovenija/iskra-zapustila-gorenjsko |website=Slovenske novice |accessdate=16 October 2018}}</ref>
Iskra continued with its development, and presented its first systemic solution in 1964. The bureau for railway automation, BAŽ, was founded.
In the 1970s, Iskra developed into the largest Yugoslavian company for [[electromechanics]], [[telecommunications]], [[electronics]] and [[automation]].,<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.iskra46-90.com/za_medije/PR_ISKRA_gradivo.pdf |title=Pregledna razstava Iskra: Neuvrščeno oblikovanje 1946-1990 |language=Slovenian |accessdate=6 September 2010}}</ref> proving itself time and time again with exceptional industrial design in telephony, measuring instruments, and machinery. At the start of the 1990s, Iskra’s logo was on all electrical devices, and our product portfolio was expanded with measuring instruments, short-wave navy radio receivers, drilling machines, movie projectors, etc.
In 1989, Iskra SOZD consisted of the following organizations:<ref>{{citation | title=Iskra: Vodič po Iskri | year=1989 | publisher=Iskra Commerce, dejavnost marketinških raziskav in komuniciranja | place=Ljubljana, Slovenia }}</ref> * Iskra Banka * Iskra Commerce * Iskra Servis * Iskra Telematika * [[Iskra Delta]] * Iskra Kibernetika * Iskra električna orodja * Iskra Elektrozveze * Iskra Merilna elektronika * Iskra Elektrooptika * Iskra Avtomatika * Iskra Orodja * Iskra Elementi * Iskra Mikroelektronika * Iskra Antene * Iskra Elekroakustika * Iskra Elektromotorji * Iskra Videomatika * Iskra Rotomatika * Iskra Avtoelektrika * Iskra Kondenzatorji * Iskra Baterije Zmaj * Iskra Institut za kakovost * Iskra "ZORIN" * Iskra Invest servis * Iskra High School
Following the breakup of Yugoslavia, it is now a company in [[Slovenia]]. The company's operations in Slovenia were divided into many separate companies, including [[Iskratel]], [[Iskra Avtoelektrika]], [[Iskraemeco]], [[Iskra Fotona|Fotona]], [[Iskra Amesi]], [http://www.iskra.eu Iskra, elektro in elektronska industrija, d.d. (Iskra d.d. for short)] <ref>[http://www.iskra.eu/company/contact_information/ Iskra d.d. Web site] (Source for Iskra d.d. only)</ref>
== TODAY ==
Iskra d.d. has been the largest knowledge hub in the region for 70 years. <ref> https://www.iskra.eu/en/Iskras-Strategic-Milestones/] </ref> Iskra d.d. is operating in the areas of * Energy sector * Electrotechnical components * Efficient Installations * Traffic * Telecommunications * Security, supply and facility management

{{For|the martial art KFM|Batman Begins#Keysi Fighting Method}} {{Use dmy dates|date=April 2014}} {{Use Irish English|date=April 2014}} {{refimprove|date=May 2008}} {{Infobox radio station| name = Kfm | image = Kfm_nAAS_logo.png| airdate = 2004 | frequency = 97.6 & 97.3 [[MHz]]| area = [[County Kildare]] | format = Contemporary | coordinates = {{Coord|53.215229|-6.707827|display=inline,title}} | language = English
[[Irish language|Irish]]https://kfmradio.com/content/ceol-agus-caint-tuesdays-7pm | owner = Co. Kildare FM Radio Ltd.| slogan =Proud To Be Yours | website = [http://www.kfmradio.com/ www.kfmradio.com] | webcast = [https://kfmradio.com/listen-live-player.html] |}} '''Kfm''' is an [[Radio in Ireland|Irish radio station]] based in [[Naas]], serving [[County Kildare]], [[Republic of Ireland|Ireland]].{{Cite web|url=http://www.bci.ie/licensed_operators/local_radio_kfm.html |title=Licensed Operators: Kfm |publisher=bci.ie |accessdate=29 March 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100115065924/http://www.bci.ie/licensed_operators/local_radio_kfm.html |archivedate=15 January 2010 |df= }} Kfm broadcasts on 97.6fm and 97.3fm to all parts of county Kildare 24 hours a day from the state-of-the-art Kfm Broadcast Centre, Newhall, Naas, Co. Kildare and around the world on its website and IPhone and Android apps. It began broadcasting in 2004, having won a ten-year franchise for the county from the [[Broadcasting Commission of Ireland]]. Kildare had previously been part of a combined franchise with [[County Carlow]] and was served by [[CKR FM]], who did not get their licence renewed. The station, with a contemporary format, caters for an audience from 15+ upwards. In January 2014, Kfm was successful in the renewal of its broadcast licence by the BAI for another 10-year term. Kfm transmitters are based on Slive Thuile, County Dublin - to serve the north of Kildare on 97.6Fm and in Rossmore, Co. Laois to serve the south of the county on 97.3FM. Kfm's broadcast area is the most station saturated in the Republic of Ireland, primarily due to the close proximity to Dublin City. Despite the intense competition, for the period from April 2013 to March 2014, Kfm is the most listened to radio station across the week in county Kildarehttp://www.ipsos/mrbi/jnlr{{dead link|date=December 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} The station has been nominated for a number of PPI awards and in 2011 won the FAI’s Communications Award (Radio). Company CEO: Clem Ryan; Programme Director: Paul Power, Sales Manager: Bertie McDermott: News Editor: Ciara Plunkett The station’s major shareholder is renowned horse trainer Dermot Weld. Other shareholders and/or directors include company chairman accountant Bernard Hurley; Kfm CEO Clem Ryan; Managing Director of Mongey Communications; Naas David Mongey; 4FM CEO and majority shareholder of East Coast FM Sean Ashmore; Managing Director of the National Ploughing Association Anna May McHugh; Dermot Weld Racing General Manager Mark Weld; and The Buggyman, Kill, Managing Director Liam Ross. ==References== {{reflist}} [http://www.ipsos/mrbi/jnlr www.ipsos/mrbi/jnlr]{{dead link|date=December 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} ==External links== * [http://www.kfmradio.com Official website] {{Local radio in Ireland}} {{Media in County Kildare}} [[Category:Media in County Kildare]] [[Category:Naas]] [[Category:Radio stations in the Republic of Ireland]] [[Category:Radio stations established in 2004]] {{Ireland-media-stub}} {{Europe-radio-station-stub}}

{{Infobox building |name = Le Formentor |image = Formentor Monaco.jpg |location = 27, Avenue Princesse Grace, Larvotto, Monaco |coordinates = {{coord|43.745449|7.431502|display=it}} |status = Complete |start_date = |completion_date = 1981 |building_type = |architectural_style = Modernist |roof = |floor_count = 27 |elevator_count = |cost = |floor_area = |architect = |structural_engineer= |main_contractor = |developer = [[J. B. Pastor et fils]] |owner = Groupe Pastor |management = |references = }} '''Le Formentor''' is a high-rise residential building in [[Monaco]].
==Location== It is located at 27 [[Avenue Princesse Grace]] in the [[Larvotto]] district of Monaco.<ref name="groupepastor">[http://www.groupepastor.mc/en/parc/004_le_formentor.html Groupe Pastor: Le Formentor]</ref><ref name="structurae">[http://structurae.net/structures/le-formentor Le Formentor], [[Structurae]]</ref><ref name="emporis">[http://www.emporis.com/buildings/124204/formentor-monaco-monaco Formentor], [[Emporis]]</ref>
==History== The construction of the building was completed in 1981.<ref name="structurae"/> It was built by the Monegasque construction firm, [[J. B. Pastor et fils]].<ref>[http://jbpastoretfils.mc/?page_id=727&lang=en J. B. Pastor et fils: History]</ref> It is owned by the Groupe Pastor,<ref name="groupepastor"/> whose offices are located in the building.<ref>[http://jbpastoretfils.mc/?page_id=3411&lang=en J.B. Pastor et fils S.A.M. Groupe Pastor]</ref> It is 27-storey high, at 78.00 metre.<ref name="emporis"/> It was built in concrete in the [[Modernist architecture|modernist architectural style]].<ref name="emporis"/>
Monaco Modern’Art, an art gallery, is located in the building.<ref>[http://www.monacomodernart.mc/contact/ Monaco Modern’Art: Contact]</ref> The consulate of [[Uruguay]] in Monaco is also located in Le Formentor.<ref>[http://en.gouv.mc/Policy-Practice/Monaco-Worldwide/Diplomacy-and-International-Presence/bilateral-relations/All-the-countries/Uruguay Gouvernement Princier: Principaute de Monaco: Representation of Oriental Republic of Uruguay in the Principality de Monaco]</ref>

{{Infobox station | name = Marjanishvili | type = {{TBILISIMETRO type}} | style = | image = Metro station Mardzhanishvili.jpg | image_size = | image_caption = Station Hall | address = | coordinates = {{coord|41.709625|N|44.797981|E|display=title,inline}} | line = {{TBILISIMETRO-line1}} | other = | structure = Underground | platform = | depth = | levels = | tracks = 2 | parking = | bicycle = | baggage_check = | opened = {{date|1966-01-11|mdy}} | closed = | rebuilt = | electrified = | ADA = | code = | owned = [[Tbilisi Metro]] | zone = | smartcardname = | smartcardstatus = | former = | passengers = | pass_year = | pass_percent = | pass_system = | mpassengers = | services = {{s-rail|title=Tbilisi Metro}} {{s-line|system=TBILISIMETRO|line=Akhmeteli-Varketili|previous=Sadguris Moedani I|next=Rustaveli}} | map_locator = }} {{Akhmeteli-Varketili Line|left}} The '''Marjanishvili''' ({{lang-ka|მარჯანიშვილი}}) is a station on the [[Akhmeteli-Varketili Line]] of the [[Tbilisi Metro]]. It opened on January 11, 1966. The station is named after [[Kote Marjanishvili]], a Georgian theater director.
==External links== *{{en icon}} [https://web.archive.org/web/20130622072113/http://www.tbilisi.gov.ge/index.php?lang_id=ENG&sec_id=2211 Marjanishvili station page at Tbilisi Municipal Portal]

{{Infobox organization | name = ''Médecins du monde'' | logo = | type = Medical humanitarian organisation | founded_date = {{start-date|1980}} | founder = [[Bernard Kouchner]] and others | headquarters = [[Paris]], [[France]] | origins = | key_people = | area_served = Worldwide | focus = | method = | budget = €135 million | budget_year = 2014 | num_volunteers = 4,000 | num_employees = | num_members = | subsid = | homepage = {{url|http://www.medecinsdumonde.org/}} | footnotes = }}
'''''Médecins du monde''''' (MdM; {{IPA-fr|medsɛ̃ dy mɔ̃d}}) or '''Doctors of the World,''' provides emergency and long-term medical care to the world's most vulnerable people. It also advocates to end health inequities.
It was founded in 1980 by a group of 15 French physicians, including [[Bernard Kouchner]]. It works in both the developed and developing world.
==History== MdM was formally established on 1 February 1980. Its goals were "[http://www.medecinsdumonde.org/qui-sommes-nous/notre-histoire#sthash.J4OlB4qQ.dpuf to go where others will not, to testify to the intolerable, and to volunteer"].
Its origins lay in a 1979 intervention to assist a drifting boat of Vietnamese refugees in the South China Sea. Kouchner, with volunteer doctors, journalists, and others organized a hospital boat, [http://www.la-croix.com/Actualite/Monde/Grace-a-l-Ile-de-Lumiere-des-milliers-de-Vietnamiens-ont-reconstruit-leur-vie-2013-08-08-996240 L'Île de lumière], to provide medical care and to report the refugees' suffering.
MdM was founded as Bernard Kouchner and 14 others doctors split from the group he previously founded, [[Médecins Sans Frontières|Medecins Sans Frontiers]] (MSF, or Doctors Without Borders). It has been reported Kouchner felt that MSF was giving up its founding principle of ''témoignage'' ("witnessing"), which refers to aid workers making the atrocities they observe known to the public.
Kouchner was president of MdM from 1980 to 1982. In 1989, the foundation of MdM Spain paved the way for the creation of the MdM international network. In 2015, the MdM global network consisted of fifteen associations; France (founded 1980), Spain (founded 1989), Greece (founded 1990), Italy and Switzerland (both founded 1993), Sweden (founded 1994), [[Cyprus]] (founded 1995 by [[Elena Theoharous]]<ref name="irishT_MdM">{{cite news | first= | last= | pages= | language =| title=Aid mission: boat departs Cyprus | date=2008-12-30 | work=[[Irish Times]] | url=http://www.irishtimes.com/newspaper/world/2008/1230/1230581468701.html |accessdate=2008-12-31 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5dSrxJum5 |archivedate=2008-12-30 }}</ref>), [[Argentina]] (founded 1998), Belgium, Canada and Portugal (all founded 1999), as well as in Germany, the United Kingdom, Japan, the Netherlands, and the USA.
==Doctors of the World USA==
Doctors of the World USA, also known as MdM USA, was founded in 1990 by famous doctor and activist [[Jonathan Mann (WHO official)|Jonathan Mann]]. The group ultimately separated from the MdM network in 2006, and became [[HealthRight International]].
[http://www.doctorsoftheworld.org Doctors of the World USA] is the 15th chapter of the MDM network. It was re-founded by committed humanitarian activists in 2011, with Dr Abby Stoddard as its founding chair. Since 2016, Fraser Mooney is the Executive Director.
== Doctors of the World UK == In 1998, Doctors of the World UK became a registered charity in England and Wales and initially only contributed to Médecins du Monde international work. It launched its UK Programme in 2006, when they opened [https://www.theguardian.com/society/2015/dec/27/doctors-of-the-world-guardian-observer-charity-appeal-2015 a clinic in Bethnal Green], in east London. The clinic provides information and medical assistance to people who cannot access mainstream health services, such as undocumented migrants, asylum seekers and the homeless.
After the Ebola crisis West Africa in 2014, it helped run [http://blogs.bmj.com/bmj/2015/09/21/andy-young-and-sarah-collis-the-real-ebola-heroes-will-not-be-getting-medals/ a treatment centre] in Moyamba, Sierra Leone. DOTW UK volunteer Professor Bulstrode was [https://www.bma.org.uk/news/2016/january/doctors-honoured-in-fight-against-ebola awarded a CBE] for his involvement in the Ebola crisis. It is currently providing healthcare for refugees and migrants in [https://www.doctorsoftheworld.org.uk/pages/international-work several countries in Europe], including Greece and Croatia, and [https://www.doctorsoftheworld.org.uk/blog/entry/the-people-are-scared-helping-those-left-behind-by-ukraines-forgotten- Ukraine].
Drs. [[Chris van Tulleken|Chris]] and Xand van Tulleken, who present the CBBC series ''[[Operation Ouch!]]'', are [http://www.vantullekenbrothers.com/dow/ Board Members of DOTW UK].
==Operations==
MdM programs focus on [[Médecins du Monde#Initiatives|'''four priority areas''']]: Conflict and Crisis, Harm Reduction, Maternal and Child Health, and Migrant Populations.
It works wherever there is war, natural disasters, disease, famine, poverty or exclusion. In 2018, Doctors of the World (MdM) provided care in 79 countries with over 300 programs in North and South America, Europe, Africa and Asia.
[http://old.medecinsdumonde.org/gb/Publications/Rapport-Moral-2014 In 2015, MdM had more than 300 projects in more than 80 countries]. In contrast to many other humanitarian NGOs, MdM worked in both developed and developing countries, and ran both emergency and long-term development projects.
==Financial Model==
In 2018, the Doctors of the World international network had a budget of some 250 million euros, and provided services to more than 6.5 million people worldwide. It allocated 78.5% of its budget to programs.15.5% to fundraising, and 6% to operating expenses.
==Surveillance by British and American intelligence agencies revealed==
In December 2013, documents released by [[National Security Agency]] whistle blower [[Edward Snowden]] revealed that British and American intelligence agencies had been carrying on secret surveillance of several humanitarian organizations including Médecins du Monde. Leigh Daynes, Executive Director of Doctors of the World UK said that he was "bewildered by these extraordinary allegations of secret surveillance. Our doctors, nurses and midwives are not a threat to national security. There is absolutely no reason for our operations to be secretly monitored." Other humanitarian organizations targeted include the [[United Nations]] Development Programme, the children's charity [[UNICEF]], and the head of the [[Economic Community of West African States]].<ref>[https://www.theguardian.com/uk-news/2013/dec/20/gchq-targeted-aid-agencies-german-government-eu-commissioner GCHQ and NSA targeted charities, Germans, Israeli PM and EU chief | UK news | The Guardian<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref>
